ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Language models.

A general grasp of simple probability and computational linguistics. A knowledge and basic applicatory experience with many language modeling algorithms and a view of the problem computational linguistics is trying to solve.
computational linguistics topics, such as Bayesian and logistic regression classification, n-grams, hidden Markov models, CKY parsing, finite state transducers
Gained an understanding of some of the ways to represent natural language in computers. Learned many techniques used in computational linguistics.
Language from a programming point of view: models of analyzing language, methods and algorithms to process language, the fundamental probability and math behind language models.
Some python coding, basics of computational linguistics

Natural language processing in Python, performing tasks such as text analysis, document classification, and sentence generation using tools such as Naive Bayes and Logistic Regression classifier, Ngram modes, Regular Expression, Context-Free Grammer, and Finite State Transducers.
Learned a lot about language models. The class was a good introduction to computational linguistics.
We learned about the intersection of linguistics and mathematics: language models, hidden markov models, and context-free grammars took up a big part of the course.
Linguistics probability models, coding of different models
I learned about different models and algorithms that computers use to process speech and text.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths: the material is interesting and Professor Frank is very nice.

Strengths - very good, clear, and thorough instruction. Topics were very well explained.
Weaknesses - programming assignments can be quite complex given the course's overall difficulty

Bob Frank is an extremely engaging and passionate lecturer and made the class interesting, even at 9 am. Throughout the course there was a bit too much probability notation used that made following the lectures difficult at times but the concepts were always very cool. Sometimes homework was very lopsided- for weeks we would have no homework and some weeks we would have very large problem sets.
The workload of this course is not too bad, but the psets were difficult and I did not feel like we got enough clear feedback on how to improve our coding.

Strengths: Professor Frank is a really great professor; he genuinely cares about his students. The topics of the class are really interesting, and Professor Frank is good at encouraging students to ask questions.
Weaknesses: The pacing of the class really speeds up at the end, and the material gets much harder. I wish the course was a bit more consistent in terms of the difficulty level throughout the semester.

The course is very well organized with each unit's presentations, code files, and readings grouped together in Canvas. The lectures are mostly going through Powerpoints but has questions and practices in them to keep the lectures engaging. The final project is also a nice way to practice and apply the skills you learned during the course. Understanding the algorithms and statistics stuff can be a bit time-consuming if you were not familiar with them before taking the course, but it is not too bad once you catch up.
Thought it was a great class! Could have moved a little faster but I know that Ling & Comp II is also usually offered. Happened to be that Ling & Comp I was the only option this semester.
Professor Frank is clearly passionate about the material and was able to keep the class engaged even over Zoom. The course material flows nicely from one topic to the next.

Professor Frank is a great professor, the material in the lectures was amazing and very interesting. However, the problem sets were only using the general concepts from the lectures, so you end up learning a lot of material for problem sets by yourself. The amount of resources and office hours was very limited, however, professor frank was very accommodating

I think the course has really interesting content and Professor Frank presents it very clearly.

However, I felt like I didn't learn overall skills or knowledge from the class. What I came away with is a basic knowledge of Python, and a set of ways computers can process speech. I don't think I developed any broader understanding of linguistic or computational concepts.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Could be improved: name lecture recordings after the topics covered in the lectures.
Live virtual lecture went very well
Generally the online format worked well for this course but keeping engagement was difficult.
The recorded lectures were helpful. Also, not having an exam was pretty nice.

The live lectures and the Canvas page were very well organized. The only problem I had was coordinating during the final project since we don't get to see each other in person and have to contact each other electronically, so there is a bit of delay in communication and collaborating over Zoom was not very engaging.
I thought this class worked pretty well virtually.
I thought the course was good in regards to covid stuff.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Sure. It's interesting.

If you have a background in CS and an interest in linguistics -- Yes!! If you have a background in linguistics and an interest in programming -- No. PLEASE heed the warnings in the syllabus that this course should only be attempted with prior programming experience. I have extensive programming knowledge, and I was very surprised by the technical challenge that was expected of people who may have started as beginners. That being said, if you are comfortable with programming (e.g. recursion, dynamic programming), this is a very interesting and engaging course.
This course is really good if you are looking for a fun class where you can learn about a new topic.

Yes, especially if you are interested in NLP and applications of computational linguistics. Professor Frank is a great person, and you will learn a lot from the lectures and the psets. If you have some CS and Python background, then this class will be a just-right difficulty.

Yes, definitely. The material is really interesting and Professor Frank is really enthusiastic about the topics. There is a lot of Python involved, so it is helpful to know that coming in, but the actual programming assignments are doable, if a little long. The final project is very open-ended and there are a lot of cool things you can do.
Yes, but only if they have a decent background in programming

I would recommend the course if you would like to learn about some useful language processing techniques without requiring too much background in linguistics or programming, since most of the linguist concepts used are well explained during the lectures and Python is a pretty easy language to pick up, although it would be difficult if you had no programming experience.
Yes! I thought it was a great class and Bob was a great professor.
Yes, Professor Frank is great and the course material is interesting. It may be more difficult without prior background in Python.

I would recommend it if you are really confident in your computation skills, because the problem sets were very computationally challenging. Get ready to start problem sets very very early and to do most of them by yourselves, because the office hours and help are very limited
I might recommend this to other students, but only if they have specific interest in this area.
